JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;Elisabeth Steiner;George Nicolaou;Giorgio Malinverni;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . The respondent Government were represented by PERSON , the former Representative of GPE at ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder of a police officer and attempted murder of several other persons . Later the police started suspecting him of theft .

On DATE the Zavolzhsk ORG ordered that the applicant be remanded in custody in pre - trial detention centre no . CARDINAL in GPE . On DATE the applicant was charged with aggravated theft under LAW “ b ” of LAW .
On DATE ORG extended the applicant 's detention until DATE . On DATE the prison administration informed the applicant that his detention had been extended until DATE .

On an unspecified date the applicant filed an application for release with the court alleging , inter alia , that he had been seriously ill . On DATE his application was dismissed by ORG by reference to LAW . The court found that the gravity of the offences alleged against him was a sufficient ground for his detention . On DATE ORG upheld that decision , adding that the applicant had been arrested DATE after he had been released after having served a previous sentence . ORG also noted that at that stage of the proceedings it was not called upon to examine the validity of proof of the applicant 's guilt .

On DATE ORG extended the applicant 's detention until DATE . The applicant was informed about that decision on DATE . The letter from ORG did not contain any reasons for extending his detention . On DATE the Deputy Prosecutor of GPE , in response to a letter from the applicant , informed him that his detention had been extended on the basis of the strength of the evidence in the case - file , his personality , and age . The prosecutor also relied on LAW ) , which enabled the prosecution to place the suspect in custody on the sole ground of the gravity of the charges against him ( see the “ Relevant domestic law ” part below ) .

On an unspecified date the applicant challenged the prosecutor 's letter of DATE before a court . On CARDINAL DATE the ORG established that LAW , referred to by the prosecutor , had been abrogated on DATE . However , the court did not order the applicant 's release .

The applicant submitted a new application for release . On DATE the ORG dismissed it , relying on the gravity of charges against the applicant and his previous convictions . That decision was upheld by ORG on DATE . The applicant submits that those decisions were taken in his absence .
On DATE ORG extended the applicant 's detention until DATE . On DATE the applicant was informed about that decision . The letter from ORG did not contain any reason for taking the decision .
According to the Government , on DATE the applicant was released under an obligation not to leave the city without permission from the prosecution .
On DATE the applicant was fully acquitted by the jury of ORG . On DATE that decision was upheld by ORG of GPE .

On DATE the newspaper “ ORG ” published an article describing the circumstances of the applicant 's arrest and detention . The applicant was mentioned in this article as an accomplice to a serious crime . The article contained an interview with an anonymous officer of ORG of ORG . It remains unclear whether the applicant has ever applied to the domestic courts for redress and what the outcome of the proceedings was , if any .
LAW of GPE provides as follows :

“ CARDINAL . Damage caused to a citizen as a result of unlawful conviction , unlawful criminal prosecution , ... unlawful detention on remand ... shall be compensated at the expense of the ORG of GPE , and in the instances provided for by law , at the expense of the ORG of the subject of GPE ... in full , irrespective of the fault of the officials of the agencies ... ”
“ Compensation for non - pecuniary damage shall be made irrespective of the fault of the person causing the damage when :
... the damage is caused to a citizen as a result of his unlawful conviction , unlawful criminal prosecution , unlawful detention on remand .... ”

The Civil Code provides that the damage caused by an unlawful criminal prosecution should be compensated irrespective of the fault of the tortfeaser . However , the notions of “ unlawful ” prosecution or detention ( see LAW ) are not developed in the relevant provisions of LAW . Certain guidelines on this subject may be obtained from Decree No . CARDINAL-X of ORG DATE , which concerns compensation for damage caused by the unlawful acts of law - enforcement agencies . CARDINAL of that LAW provides that an acquitted person has the right to obtain damages from the ORG ; the only exception concerns cases when the person was charged after making a false confession . Furthermore , in the case of PERSON ( published in the Bulletin of ORG , DATE г. , ORG , page CARDINAL ) , ORG of GPE used the following wording : “ ... unlawful attribution of criminal liability , namely when an acquittal judgment was given ... ” . These words , as well as the subsequent judicial practice , suggest that the domestic courts regard criminal proceedings which ended with an acquittal to be “ unlawful ” at the outset . Therefore , if there was an acquittal , pre - trial detention would be “ unlawful ” even if all the substantive and procedural rules were complied with when it was imposed .

Under LAW Code of Criminal Proceedings ( CCrP ) , in force as from DATE , the acquitted person has the right to compensation for pecuniary ( LAW ) and non - pecuniary damage ( LAW ) caused by prosecution ( LAW ) and unlawful application of measures of restraint , including pre - trial detention ( LAW ) . Under LAW of the CCrP , if information about the arrest or prosecution of a person was made public in the media , the acquitted person , his relatives , or a public prosecutor may request the publication of a retraction by the same medium .
